11:20 am
BE11:20am

Kier has reported a mixed trading outlook divisionally and much higher
exceptionals than H1, but this needs to be put in context. In terms of trading, we reduce estimates to a level we believe provides an achievable performance. Meantime, exceptionals in part relate to the much-needed re-shaping and we would note that even with lower PBT estimates and cash costs of exceptionals we should expect net debt to decline - driven by disposals and reduced capital employed in asset-intensive businesses. Our view therefore remains that Kier is a special situation where substantial recovery potential will be reflected as debt reduces; FY results are inevitably convoluted, but are a first step on the road to recovery.

Buildings (EBIT +13%) and Developments & Housing (EBIT -22%) were in line with NSe.

Importantly, cash impact of these charges were £34m in 2019 and in 2020E management guides to c£30m of additional outflow - as such, the cash impact of this large exceptional figure should not be taken out of context.

BE11:24am

Numis again:

BE11:24am

We believe it prudent to recalibrate estimates as the new management team get to grips with both market uncertainty and also structural re-shaping of the business. Accordingly, we reduce 2020E PBT and EPS by 38%. Note that PBT and net debt estimates do not assume Kier Living disposal.

chomsky BoE will be more interesting
11:25 am
BE11:25am

And Peel Hunt, who are shop.

BE11:25am

The FY19 results are consistent with our underlying assumptions and the order book is largely unchanged at £9.4bn. As expected, the strategic and contract reviews have resulted in material exceptional charges (£316m). However, these are largely non-cash and the future cash drag is limited to c£32m over the next six years. Although we are reducing our FY20 EPS by 23% to reflect a rebasing of expectations, we still assume a reduction in average net debt (prior to any disposals benefit). The disposal of Kier Living is progressing well and we are encouraged by the progress in reshaping Kier and the strengthening of the balance sheet. The new management is positioned to restore value.

BE11:26am

We reduce our FY20 EBITA from £131m to £111m. The principal changes relate to lower Infrastructure (largely Highways spending, Highways mix and elimination of HS2 assumptions) and Housing and Developments (returns on lower capital employed) assumptions. No material change to our Buildings assumptions. These reductions are mitigated by a lower central overhead (£25m vs PHe £40m). Our FY20 PBT moves from £112.5m (cons £126m) to £88.0m to give EPS of 43p from 56p. We assume a reduction in both spot debt (to £161m) and average net debt (to £400m) despite the planned elimination of £65m of supply chain finance (given the significant liquidity and facilities (£922m) headroom).

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Exceptionals totalled £316m (excluding £25m of amortisation of acquisition intangibles). Although higher than we expected (PHe £150m), the total includes costs relating to businesses for sale (£172m), restructuring costs (£56m), historic acquisitions (£29m) and contract provisions (£44m). Importantly, the future cash obligations from these charges is £32m (spread to 2026) and in line with our expectations. We have made no assumption for possible cash recoveries and the balance sheet looks to have been well scrubbed.

PBateman Sorry to bang on about kingfisher after yesterday, but a funny one for you. Google 'one kingfisher' and click the top result. Tells you all you need to know!
11:30 am
BE11:30am

As said previously. labour disputes only really seem to affect the shares of South African miners and privatised mail delivery companies.

Forester @pbateman Lol. Nice one!
BE11:30am

Today's strength is more about a Morgan Stanley sector thing.

BE11:31am

The upshot of which is:

11:30 am
BE11:31am

We take a fresh look at Airlines and arrive at a Cautious View: intense competition, weak macro, labour disputes and rising environmental costs will put pressure on earnings and likely be a drag on share prices. We prefer IAG on valuation grounds and would avoid Ryanair and Deutsche Lufthansa. Airlines have been a poor investment over the past two years, is it time to buy? We think it may be too soon: we see three headwinds for the sector in Europe, which are not fully priced in the shares. (1) Competition is not yet receding at a fast enough pace. (2) Fuel and environmental costs could be on the rise and we think future fuel efficiency gains are less of a cost advantage than the market perceives. (3) Labour costs look likely to exceed inflation. And, while the sector is trading close to trough multiples, it is not on trough earnings (or returns), and we see scope for further downside. Our earnings estimates are, on average, 7% below consensus for CY19 EPS. Long-term, we see some scope for optimism. We estimate margins implied in consensus estimates are below managements' targets for all Airlines, so assuming their medium-term ambitions are met, we see significant upside potential for all stocks under our coverage (included in our bull cases). However, we think the best time to own airlines, based on history, is when returns and cash flows start to inflect - we do not think we are at that point yet: trough multiples, without signs of recovery, are not a good enough reason to buy the sector. How to play the sector? On a relative basis, we prefer IAG (Overweight, PT €6.30). While we acknowledge there are risks to the investment story (IT, labour, macro), these are more than priced in and we think IAG's premium returns are not appreciated by investors. On the other hand, we would argue that best-in-class Ryanair (Underweight, PT €8.00) is unlikely to achieve the same level of premium returns versus peers that it has historically; competitors' returns have recovered somewhat and Ryanair will have to invest (i.e. reduce unit revenues) to ensure its leadership in the EU and grow above market rates. We think the premium contraction has been overlooked. Risks to the earnings outlook for Deutsche Lufthansa (Underweight, PT €12.00) persist and even if the group succeeds in normalizing returns, execution and, hence, pricing in the earnings rebound, will take time in our view. We think our ratings, on a relative basis, should stand regardless of the macro backdrop. We rate Air France-KLM, easyJet and Wizz Air Equal-weight. Where we could be wrong. Due to weak demand and, in part, due to the grounding of the 737 MAX, capacity growth for winter 2020 and summer 2020 has been coming down. Should we see a more supportive macro environment (stronger demand and fixed capacity), it is possible that unit revenues exceed our estimates and airlines stocks outperform the broader market.

nightingale20201 @Shmo...fyi, India just passed the law yesterday to end e-cigs production & sales in the country
BE11:31am

And for IAG specifically:

BE11:31am

The IAG investment case is not without risks: macro, strikes, IT issues are hurdles facing the group, but we argue these are priced in. IAG has a strong track record of cost cutting and delivery of targets, which is not reflected in the share price. The skies haven't been blue for IAG. IAG is operating under difficult conditions: its largest carrier BA has been suffering pilot strikes, which we estimate could cost the group up to €150mn in 2019, IT issues, and it needs to reinvest to improve services and keep its market share on its premium (and profitable) classes. On top, Brexit could have a negative impact due to a weak GBP and potentially soft demand should we see a weak economy in Europe and in the UK. So why are we positive? We think the negatives are priced in, and by more than peers. The shares have declined despite consensus earnings not moving (unlike peers), leading to a PE multiple contraction of 1.5x year to date, 0.2x more than peers. Moreover, we view IAG's medium-term targets as less challenging than peers: IAG's EBIT target margin range of 12-15% does not require improvement (unlike peers) - the group has been been reporting margins within this range since 2017, and it has one of the highest margins across EU airlines. Finally, IAG has a strong track record on executing self help: it was able to achieve a decline in unit cost by 19%, 800bps better than the peer average in 2012-2018. And, we estimate it will continue to generate premium returns over peers.Valuation is also supportive. Despite having above average FCF generation, returns and cost execution, IAG is trading at trough multiples both in absolute (3.8x 2-year forward PE) and relative terms (0.6x sector PE, vs historical trading at 0.8x). Moreover, IAG EV/IC relative to premium over cost of capital is amongst the most attractive in the sector. This signals that the negatives have been priced in by more than peers. And, if the outlook improves and IAG delivers on its medium-term targets (our bull case), the upside to shares would be over 100%.

marktime Actually some strike days have been called off but the dispute is not "off", no pay or profit agreement announced
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Where could we be wrong? Due to the size of its fleet and investment plans, we forecast IAG will have one of the lower fuel efficiency gains over the next 5 years, therefore any increase in fuel/carbon would hit it more than peers in the longer term. Moreover, weaker than expected demand could drive yields lower, reducing earnings and cash flow. The dispute with UK pilots has not yet been resolved and could have a higher cost to BA than we model. Moreover, IAG has restrictions on non-EU shareholders, which could limit liquidity of shares.

BE11:43am

Our Tobacco coverage (PMI, BAT, Altria, Imperial) is trading on a c10x F12m P/E multiple (consensus estimates), a c25% discount to the market (Euro STOXX 600) and well-below its 10-year average premium of 15%, albeit this is unsurprising given the heightened legislative scrutiny and evolving business models (shift towards NGP's) that tobacco companies have seen in recent years. YTD, the tobacco companies under our coverage have seen their F12m P/E multiple hold broadly flat, but this represents a c10% relative de-rating to the overall market.

BE11:43am

We remain broadly constructive on the tobacco sector, believing the market continues to underappreciate the potential opportunity for NGP's, in our view. Our preference is for Buy-rated PMI and BAT, both of which we view as best-placed to exploit the growing NGP opportunity, with both holding compelling portfolios in this space. On PMI specifically, the potential merger with Altria remains a key debate; but we recently concluded that following the recent pullback in PMI shares, it remains the best place to be irrespective of whether the merger goes ahead or not. We are Neutral-rated on Altria and Imperial.

We think the chances of a deal are increasing — When PM and MO first
confirmed they were in talks, we said the chances of the merger proceeding were about 50-50, given the fall in the shares and the skepticism from shareholders. But if this sort of pressure was going to put management off, we would have expected a relatively speedy announcement saying so. As there has been no such announcement, we think the chances of the merger going ahead have increased.

Rather we think MergedCo will simply own a passive 35% stake in Juul, which will be an interesting asset but not more.

hagilon Trump in@FoxNews:"I'm not delighted with Powell, but his job is not in danger.""Powell doesn't know very well how to play this game.""The Fed should cut rates further when other central banks do."
11:49 am
BE11:50am

And then there were the bloody dots.

nightingale20201 the rate market this am looks like pricing in more curve inversion in the short end.....
BE11:50am

Here's Reid at DB.

BE11:50am

The signal is a somewhat divided committee. The median dot shows no further cuts in the remainder of 2019 or 2020. However, 7 of the 17 dots favour one more 25bp cut this year, albeit no-one expects more than a 25bp cut. There are also 8 dots in 2020 which favour a fed funds rate 25bps below where it is now. What is interesting however is that there are 5 dots which are 25bps above the current rate for this year and 7 above the current rate for 2020. In fact, one of those in 2020 is 50bps above the current rate. So, one way of summing that up is that the doves aren’t particularly dovish and there is a clear group of hawks on the committee. The sharp sell-off across rates immediately following the statement certainly reflected that.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

As for the statement itself, there was very little change. The reference to “muted inflation pressures” was kept despite CPI strengthening in recent weeks while the only real change of note was the reference to household spending rising at a “strong pace”. The summary of economic projections was a wash with the exception of 2019 growth being upgraded to 2.2%. As for Powell’s press conference, unlike previous meetings there weren’t all that many talking points. The general feeling was that Powell was very considered and balanced in his responses with a broad aim of not wanting to guide the market. That was particularly the case when going out of the way not to repeat the mid-cycle adjustment language. Our economists summed it up by saying that Powell reinforced the message that the Fed that continues to see a favourable baseline outlook, albeit one buffeted by significant downside risks from weak global growth and trade policy uncertainty. They continue to expect 75bps more of rate cuts through Q1 next year with a possible announcement also of a resumption of balance sheet growth next month.

tadam I would like to see more U.S. coverage. Thanks.
BE11:51am

In terms of what markets did, treasury yields had been falling for much of the day leading into the meeting but by the time Powell was finished speaking had pretty much reversed. That was particularly the case at the short-end where 2y yields ended +3.7bps higher at 1.762% having traded as low as 1.660% seconds before the statement and dot plot was released. With 10y yields (-0.5bps) not quite fully reversing, that meant the 2s10s curve, which was as ‘steep’ as 9.0bps, flattened to 3.0bps. This morning it’s trading at similar levels. There’s also just over 2 cuts still priced in by the end of this year.

Meanwhile equity markets were initially much weaker seemingly in reaction to the dots, however recovered as Powell spoke. The S&P 500 ended +0.03% - a rare albeit modest gain on a Fed meeting day - however did trade as low as -0.91% intraday while the NASDAQ ended -0.11%. The fact that Powell sounded fairly upbeat about the domestic economy, all things considered, but also hinted that the Fed will react to weaker data probably explained the turnaround for equities. Banks (+0.66%) notably outperformed, with the short-end rates selloff and Powell’s pushback on negative rates helping.

hagilon Yesterday, a journalist criticizing the slow pace with which the Fed responded to the liquidity crisis these days.Powell: "We weren't expecting something so strong, we were surprised and I think most market participants too. Although it doesn't have to affect anything else."
marktime A 9% kick up on flat Q1s needs some explanation, Plus and CMC Markets following at a distance
BE11:52am

And here's UBS's rate strategy desk, saying the bond sell-off is running out of steam.

hagilon ...............
11:52 am
BE11:53am

Over the past three weeks, bond yields have increased sharply – led by the US. The increase in US yields was the result of three forces: re-pricing of the FOMC; reduced geopolitical risks (mostly Brexit and the US/China trade tension); and a boom in USD
fixed rate supply. Each of these forces seems to have largely played out, so the bond sell-off looks mature. We are bullish duration at current levels.

The re-pricing of the US short end looks mature. At ~60bps, the gap between the median forecast for 2020 and the market is the smallest it has been all year. Further, seven of seventeen participants favour a further cut. Moreover, UBSe expects the FOMC to ease by more than the market has priced in 2020.

BE11:53am

The recent sharp acceleration of USD fixed rate supply was larger than historical relationships would suggest. Business surveys remain depressed, so fresh capex plans are probably not driving funding requirements. Therefore more funding today means less tomorrow. We may still see supply for re-financing purposes, but that should have a lower impact on the level of yields.

BE11:53am

We recommend buying US 10yrs at 1.79%, target a move to 1.45%, and place a stop at 1.95%. We continue to expect that US yields will head to new lows as the US economy stalls in H1'20.

2s10s "2s10s curve, which was as ‘steep’ as 9.0bps, flattened to 3.0bps. " hey I'm name checked there.
11:54 am
BE11:54am

And back to Exane for something written for English speakers.

BE11:55am

The Fed’s economic forecasts were almost unchanged at this meeting. Core inflation is still expected to be close to the Fed’s target in end-2020 while the unemployment rate is expected to be below its long-run level. In that context, it is logical that FOMC members do not see the need for a full cycle of monetary easing. In our view, more aggressive easing would require 1) the forecast of a jump in unemployment, 2) falling inflation expectations or 3) a tightening in financial conditions.

leckford despite being french
PBateman brexit docos shared with eu comm - 'bout time..
BE11:55am

We maintain our view of one more rate cut by year-end. We see the group of 7-8 Fed members forecasting another rate cut as more influential than the rest of the Committee. Further, we expect global growth to remain weak in the coming months given the recent spike in uncertainty. We assume no meaningful change in trade policy in the coming months. Looking to 2020, the rebound in inflation and the absence of economy-wide recession should lead the Fed to pause.

H1 results [...] showed impressive top-line momentum, with sales up by 36% year on year. However, increased operating costs to support the rapid scaling of the business meant that operating margins have fallen back in the period. Furthermore, the company has outlined plans to take a more cautious approach to acquisitions until there is greater certainty around the UK environment in a post-Brexit world. We update our numbers to reflect the results and reduce our price target modestly to 250p.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

In light of the heightened political and
economic uncertainty in the UK, CPC has indicated that it plans to take a
more prudent approach to M&A for the foreseeable future. While
management has not entirely ruled out acquisitions in the coming months,
it has made it clear that the main priority will be reducing debt and
opening its development sites. Despite that more cautious approach, the
ultimate ambition of reaching 65 pubs (from 47 trading sites at present) is
unchanged. Furthermore, we still forecast notable sales and earnings
growth in the next two years, driven by the opening of large development
sites in Exeter, Cambridge and Bath next year.

BE11:59am

CPC currently trades at 12.9x 2021E EV/EBITDA (the first year
in which all of its development assets will contribute for a full 12 months).
